- Hello and welcome to our
question and answer session
on data protection in AWS cloud.
My name is Harry Mallalieu.
I'm a senior technical program manager

in the Worldwide Public
Sector Security team.
As a team,
we work to identify and remove
security compliance related blockers

to cloud adoption for
public sector customers.
With me today is Nika.

Nika, will you introduce
yourself for our audience?
- Hello, my name is Nika Lippert.

I'm a security and
compliance strategist at AWS
in the EMEA region with focus on the UK.

My job is to explain security
and compliance at AWS,

making it better understandable
for our customers.
These sessions help not only your clients,

but also assist regulators
in understanding
the capabilities of cloud customers.
- Awesome, during our talk today,

we're gonna discuss the most
common questions we hear
from customers and attempt to answer them
in simple language.
"Why simple language?" I hear you ask.
That's because it concerns legal aspects,
and we are not lawyers.
- And no, this is not legal advice.
We're simply going to summarize

publicly available information
and provide context.
You as customers will still need
to evaluate the information.
Naturally, we will provide links
to the sources of information afterwards.

- In this video, we'll
be doing a role play.
I'll be providing the role
of a public sector customer operating
in Germany and asking the questions,

whilst Nika will use her
subject matter knowledge

as a AWS security strategist
to answer the questions.
So let's get started.

My data protection officer
says that it's not permissible
to use the services of a US hyperscaler
or its European subsidiaries.

I'm sure this is a question
that AWS hears a lot.
What is the answer for customers?

- Indeed, this is a
question we have often.
All AWS services can be used in accordance
with applicable data protection laws,

especially the General Data
Protection Regulation, the GDPR.
This was also the case
after the so-called Schrems II ruling
since mid-July 2023,
following the introduction

of appropriate guarantees
by the American government.
There's also, again, an adequacy decision
between USA and EU,

clearly confirming that the
transfer of personal data
to the USA is permissible.
The adequacy decision provides
both public and private organizations

with a simpler and legally
secure way to transfer data
between Europe and the USA.

Consequently, the use of
cloud services offered
within Europe by US companies
is also compliant with the law.
Due to this adequacy decision,

customers do not
necessarily have to resort

to the standard contractual
clause as before,
following the Schrems II ruling.
For customers still wishing to do so
because they want to cover data transfers

to other third countries
apart from the USA,

the adequacy decision
also provides a remedy

for the so-called transfer
impact assessment.
Here, due to the introduced guarantees,

customers can come to
a positive assessment
of the level of protection in the USA.

So to summarize, or in
short, the answer is yes.
It has always been and it is permissible
to use a US hyperscaler and its services.

One just needs appropriate
legal transfer mechanism,
such as the adequacy decision
or guarantees that the data of Europeans
in the USA will be treated adequately,
and such guarantees exist.
Apart from the already existing technical
and organizational measures,

which are relevant in a
transfer impact assessment
since July 2023,
at the latest.

Either way, customer, even
before the Schrems II ruling,

for example, even if no
transfer was envisaged
or might occur,
already had to ensure
that only authorized personnel
could access personal data in plain text,
so with that readable data.
And it was and remains necessary

to take suitable measures
on a risk-based approach

to comply with the General
Data Protection Regulation.
- Really interesting, Nika,
and I think that much of this
is likely to be new information
for some of our customers.

Our company's data protection
officer will be pleased
that there's finally clarity
regarding the legal transfer mechanism,

but they'll probably have
some follow-up questions.
What are these suitable measures
and safeguards that you've mentioned?
- It is about controlling who, how, where,

and for what purpose accesses
this protected information.
Encryption combined with access control
is one such measurement.

Of course, the cloud
services must support these,

just as a processing
location must be known
to cloud customers,
allowing them to control the storage
and processing location autonomously.
These and other criteria are audited

for compliance by
independent third parties.
For example, in the code of conduct

of the Cloud Infrastructure
Service Providers, the CISPE,

cloud customers can rely
on this audit result.
The Federal Commission for Data Protection
and Freedom of Information
has included a position communicated
by the European Data Protection Authority,
and its activity report for the year 2022.

Specifically, it writes
about the guidelines

on approved certifications
and codes of conduct
as instrument for third country transfers,

stating that the confirmation
of certification,

based on codes of conduct,
such as the CISPE,

provides customers with suitable
guarantees under the GDPR.
As of May 2024,
AWS has certified 107 AWS services,
according to the CISPE code of conduct.
- I understand, as a customer,

it's my responsibility to
use the services correctly.

It's AWS's responsibility
to offer the services

in a manner that provide me
with choices and flexibility.

For example, I have the choice
of how to encrypt my data.
And by looking on AWS Artifact
for details around specific attestations

and certifications, such
as the C5 certification,

then I should be able to
provide the desired detail
to both my security organization
and data protection officer.
But then why is there still a degree

of skepticism towards
US hyperscaler services?
- Well, this dates back a long way
and is partly due to the two-times loss
of the legal transfer basis

due to the Schrems I and
Schrems II decisions.
Following the Schrems II decision,

data protection
authorities issued guidance

that additional safe
parts must be implemented

alongside the standard contractual
clauses to be effective.
These safeguards must be established
by the responsible party.

So with that, cloud customers
and not by the cloud provider.

For example, customers must
encrypt with key state control,

not with keys control
by the cloud provider.

While the keys can be applied
in the provider's clouds
or the encryption services
of the cloud provider can used,

the cloud provider must
not have access to them
and use customer keys themselves.
Additionally, providers like AWS

use specifically Hornet
hardware security models, HSM,

which are subject to a FIPS
140-2 Level 3 certification,

ensuring that a cloud provider
cannot access customer keys
stored in such an HSM,
either logically nor physically.
The way our customers use AWS services,
data transfer not only to the USA
can be excluded by a customer.
- Okay, thanks, Nika.

I have the detail that I'm
looking for in data transfers,
and I consider this element resolved,
but what about support cases?

Or if AWS receives a court
order requesting information
for criminal investigation purposes?
Those are the concerns I'm asked about
by our legal department.
- My first recommendation is always

to make support requests
on the testing environment,
where synthetic data resides.
In general, with AWS,
all support personnel does not have access
to customer data by default,

when, for example,
maintenance is performed
on a cloud service.
However, if customers explicitly request

our assistance by
opening a support ticket,

they also directly control
which information they provides.

So for example, the
day-to-day manual insert
into the support tickets

or the content they
show via screen sharing.
Furthermore, only screen contents
are securely transported over questions.

So only a few lines of an
entire database are transmitted,

thereby excluding targeted
searches by AWS staff.

And if customers then encrypt
the data, for example,
in simple storage with your customer key,

then the S3 service team
member can help them
at the bits and byte level,
but does not see the data in plain text.

And regarding the question
about a court order,
that is indeed a relevant aspect.
The laws of the country

in which the provider
offers its services apply,

whether the Federal Criminal
Police Office, INTERPOL,
or a police action in the USA

for the investigation of a
crime of times court order.

And if there are mutual
legal assistant treaties
or the Budapest Convention,
which is a multilateral agreement

on the search and
seizure of computer data,
then a service provider is subject
to such requests and must process them.
However, this does not mean

that information must
be disclosed directly.
No, because AWS cannot access

a specifically requested
data set in such way,
and if it's encrypted,

only the encrypted data
would be provided at most.
Because the Cloud Act,

which is frequently cited as
clarifying use of Data Act,

does not specifically
relate to cloud computing,

it regulates so that
neither indiscriminate
nor both data collection can be demanded.

Nor does it require the service
provider to decrypt data

or provide technical
assistance for the encryption.

Therefore, the Cloud Act is
described as encryption neutral.

These points are derived
from the fact sheet

of the Cloud Act from the
US Department of Justice.
And as final point,

the European Commission and
the US Department of Justice
have been working since 2019

on a bilateral law
agreement on the Cloud Act,

with the result that the
USA can only request data
from US citizens in Europe.

And the European member
states can only request data

concerning the citizens
located in the USA,

and each time only if there's
a binding court order.
- Great detail, Nika.
So if I recall correctly,

AWS assures me in the
supplementary addendum

that you will contest
law enforcement requests

for customer data from agencies
inside or outside the EEA,
if the request is overly broad,
or if there's reasonable grounds for it.

For example, if the
request contradicts EU law,
but how often does this actually happen?

I need more detail and
data for risk assessment.
- This is a very important aspect.
The assessment of the actual risk.

We publish these numbers
you're looking for twice a year
in our Information Request report.

We differentiate between our
e-commerce and cloud divisions.
In the second half of 2023,
Amazon, excluding AWS,
received about 27,000 requests

related to activities
on the selling platform,
nearly half of which were from Germany.
During the same periods,
AWS received about 1,500 inquiries

concerning customer
activities on the AWS cloud,

of which about a fifth
originated from Europe.
We clearly have both a team

and a process in place to
handle these inquiries.

This is also verified
in the C5 certification.
- 1,500 across the whole of AWS
doesn't sound like much over six months,
but still, for me in Europe,
it's a risk that cannot be ignored.

Can the data also be
better defined regionally
or at a country level?
How many data sets were actually released?
- The report contains more details,
so please be sure
to download and to read it.

Regarding the question of the
about a thousand inquiries,
approximately 1.5% actually
were because customer data was requested,

which is a relatively stable
value over the past years.
In most cases,

account information, such
as billing addresses,
was requested.
And as for your question about the regions

as to whether the 1.5%
also involve requests
for data from the European economic area,
we can be more explicit
and answer the following question,

how many requests
resulted in the disclosure
to the US Government of Enterprise
or government content data
located outside the United States?
The answer is straightforward, none.

- I see, I understand this
represents a theoretical risk.
Thus, I should address it not only
through technical protection measures,
such as encryption,
but also try and mitigate it.
However, the risk remains,

and it's incredibly helpful
to have data points together

to assess the likelihood
of the occurrence.
Thank you very much for the information
and the links to the sources
from which you've obtained your data.

These are official positions
of the supervisory authorities,
which are certainly helpful
to build a logical augmentation chain.
In a previous conversation,
you had pointed out that AWS

cannot conduct a transfer
impact assessment
for its services on a customer's behalf,

as these assessment
contain actual details held
by the customer,
which is key.
With what I've heard today,
and the technical data protection concept
that we as a team are currently writing,

we are now confident that we
can achieve GDPR compliance.
- You're very welcome,

and if you need any further
support in the future,

whether with your own company
data protection officer

or that of the federal
state where you're located,
or even with a strategic customer,
we are happy to assist here as well
and provide comprehensive materials
that we can share with customers.
- That's very helpful, Nika.

I must ask one more question
while I've got you here.

Are we the first customer
to deal with these sort

of compliance regulations and
laws that use AWS services

for public sector or
the healthcare sector?
Not that it should make a difference,

but it's always reassuring
to know what's possible.
Do you have any references, use cases,
or examples that you can give?
- Of course, I understand perfectly,
and yes, we have several convincing cases,
where this approaches work extremely well.
Here's some examples in Germany.
First of all,

health data in AWS, one of the
most sensitive data classes.
The Fachklinikum Mainschleife in Frankfurt
has its perks and so system on AWS.

So think about a complete
digital patient record
as the scope.
Then the Barmer insurance,

with the approval of the Federal
Office for Social Security
stores a machine learning solution on AWS.

And finally, e-learning
in Schleswig-Holstein

and Baden-Wurttemberg is
also on AWS and many more.
So you see, it's possible.

You as a customer just
need to be prepared,
do your work properly and documented.

- That brings us to the end
of our question and answer
role play on data protection in AWS cloud.
We hope you found it useful
and that it will set you up for success

when navigating security
and compliance in the cloud.

Many thanks to Nika,
our security strategist,
for sharing all of her expertise.

For more information on
everything we've discussed today,
please have a look on our website

Thank you.
